item.title: Rude as that last anon message had been, I can't help but share the sentiment that by attempting to argue for faith's place in science, this blog has strayed from its professed purpose, which appears on your "About" page as "posting the kind of scientific pictures who lead [sic] to see the science as something beautiful." It may be your blog, and you certainly have the right to post whatever you want, but the religious posturing is, frankly, becoming tiresome.
item.dc:creator: Eclectikus

A few participants more: aleshiaclarke says: Regardless of one’s faith, why not allow people to ask “what if?” Putting everyone’s ideas on the table does not impede science. The...

[[ This is a content summary only. Visit my website for full links, other content, and more! ]]

item.title: Personally, I do not believe that religion has any place in the world of science. In fact, the two are quite plainly contradictory. While it is perfectly human to fear the unknown or to be superstitious, we as scientists cannot afford to entertain such baseless ideas. Science is rooted in experiment, observation, and evidence. To be a human of faith, one must forsake critical inquiry and scientific thought. Religion, faith and superstition are simply byproducts of our evolutionary history.
item.dc:creator: Eclectikus
item.description:
Religion is not a byproduct, at least that you are thinking that a great part of philosophy, astronomy, mathematics, music, paintwork, sculpture, architecture are also byproducts....

[[ This is a content summary only. Visit my website for full links, other content, and more! ]]

item.title: Faith, construed as authentic trust, is something we all practice--and a crucial attitude in doing scientific research. Faith, as clinging to a religious dogma, however, is neither compatible with science (for it involves gullibility) nor genuinely faithful (for clinging implies a lack of trust).
item.dc:creator: Eclectikus
item.description:
Interesting. But I never say that religion (and its corresponding faith) are required in the laboratory. What I say and maintain, is that  a religious scientist, even a priest,...

[[ This is a content summary only. Visit my website for full links, other content, and more! ]]

item.title: I, too, am a Christian and am working on my second science degree - to me, the beauty of science is part of how I understand God, and I think God would be disappointed if we didn't use our brains to do science. Also, I think of Genesis 1 as basically a being outside of time trying to recount the origins of the universe to a bronze-age shepherd whose language doesn't even have a word for "science" at that point in time - in other words, I see it as metaphor and poetry, not a divine lab notebook!
item.dc:creator: Eclectikus
item.description:
Bravo! That is a crucial point. Thank you very much. Unfortunately this is an argument that is transparent to the fundamentalist atheists. But many people around the globe will...

item.title: I may be guilty of turning my passion for paleontology into a religion: if I find out someone is a creationist, I have a hard time listening to anything they say regardless of the topic. I sometimes look at articles promoting creationism out of curiosity, but I rarely can finish reading them before I become very angry. Some of my personal heroes are Carolus Linnaeus,Ernst Haeckel, Charles Darwin, and Jennifer Clack. Is this bad?
item.dc:creator: Eclectikus
item.description:
To me see Science as Religion is a big problem, and reading science books as if were the Bible is the tumoral form of this problem. But is only my point of view, you can do...

item.title: I think you are misinterpreting/reading too far into what I am saying. People with faith shouldn't be forbidden from partaking in science, as you seem to infer from my comments. However, people with faith should be recognized as carrying around heavy baggage of cognitive dissonance, as having their faith is in direct violation with rational and empirical thought associated with science. It's no coincidence that the emergence of religious skeptics coincided with the biggest scientific discoveries
item.dc:creator: Eclectikus
item.description:
Nope wikipedian, with all due respect. I understand you, but I don’t agree with you, which is nothing special. “people with faith should be recognized as carrying around heavy...
